title: Anthropologist
contents: bullet | Skill Proficiencies: Insight, Religion
bullet | Languages: Two of your choice
bullet | Equipment: A leather-bound diary, a bottle of ink, an ink pen, a set of traveler's clothes, one trinket of special significance, and a pouch containing 10 gp

description | Cultural Chameleon | Before becoming an adventurer, you spent much of your adult life away from your homeland, living among people different from your kin. You came to understand these foreign cultures and the ways of their people, who eventually treated you as one of their own. One culture had more of an influence on you than any other, shaping your beliefs and customs Choose a race whose culture you've adopted, or roll on the Adopted Culture table.
text | d8｜Culture
text | 1｜Aarakocra
text | 2｜Dwarf
text | 3｜Elf
text | 4｜Goblin
text | 5｜Halfling
text | 6｜Human
text | 7｜Lizardfolk
text | 8｜Orc

description | Feature: Adept Linguist | You can communicate with humanoids who don't speak any language you know. You must observe the humanoids interacting with one another for at least 1 day, after which you learn a handful of important words, expressions, and gestures - enough to communicate on a rudimentary level.

description | Suggested Characteristics | Anthropologists leave behind the societies into which they were born to discover what life is like in other parts of the world. They seek to see how other races and civilizations survive - or why they did not. Some anthropologists are driven by intellectual curiosity, while others want the fame and recognition that comes with being the first to discover a new people, a lost tribe, or the truth about an ancient empire's downfall.
text | d6｜Personality Trait
text | 1｜I prefer the company of those who aren't like me, including people of other races
text | 2｜I'm a stickler when it comes to observing proper etiquette and local customs
text | 3｜I would rather observe than meddle
text | 4｜By living among violent people, I have become desensitized to violence.
text | 5｜I would risk life and limb to discover a new culture or unravel the secrets of a dead one.
text | 6｜When I arrive at a new settlement for the first time, I must learn all its customs.
text | d6｜Ideal
text | 1｜Discovery. I want to be the first person to discover a lost culture. (Any)
text | 2｜Distance. One must not interfere with the affairs of another culture - even one in need of aid. (Lawful)
text | 3｜Knowledge. By understanding other races and cultures, we learn to understand ourselves. (Any)
text | 4｜Power. Common people crave strong leadership, and I do my utmost to provide it. (Lawful)
text | 5｜Protection. I must do everything possible to save a society facing extinction. (Good)
text | 6｜Indifferent. Life is cruel. What's the point in saving people if they're going to die anyway? (Chaotic)
text | d6｜Bond
text | 1｜My mentor gave me a journal filled with lore and wisdom. Losing it would devastate me.
text | 2｜Having lived among the people of a primeval tribe or clan, I long to return and see how they are faring.
text | 3｜Years ago, tragedy struck the members of an isolated society I befriended, and I will honor them.
text | 4｜I want to learn more about a particular humanoid culture that fascinates me.
text | 5｜I seek to avenge a clan, tribe, kingdom, or empire that was wiped out.
text | 6｜I have a trinket that I believe is the key to finding a long-lost society.
text | d6｜Flaw
text | 1｜Boats make me seasick.
text | 2｜I talk to myself, and I don't make friends easily.
text | 3｜I believe that I'm intellectually superior to people from other cultures and have much to teach them.
text | 4｜I've picked up some unpleasant habits living among goblins, lizardfolk, or orcs.
text | 5｜I complain about everything.
text | 6｜I wear a tribal mask and never take it off.

title: Astral Drifter
contents: bullet | Skill Proficiencies: Insight, Religion
bullet | Languages: Two of your choice (Celestial or Gith recommended)
bullet | Equipment: A set of traveler's clothes, a diary, an ink pen, a bottle of ink, and a pouch containing 10 gp
description | Longevity | You are 20d6 years older than you look, because you have spent that much time in the Astral Sea without aging.
description | Feature: Divine Contact | You gain the Magic Initiate feat from the Player's Handbook and must choose cleric for the feat.

text | In the Astral Sea, you crossed paths with a wandering deity. The encounter was brief and nonviolent, yet it made a lasting impression on you. This deity saw fit to share one secret or obscure bit of cosmic lore with you. Work with your DM to determine the details of this knowledge and its impact on the campaign.
text | Roll on the Divine Contact table to determine which deity you encountered, or work with your DM to identify a more suitable choice.
text | Divine Contact
text | d10｜Wandering Deity
text | 1｜Corellon, god of art and magic (chaotic good)
text | 2｜Tymora, god of good fortune (chaotic good)
text | 3｜Fharlanghn, god of horizons and travel (neutral good)
text | 4｜Istus, god of fate and destiny (neutral)
text | 5｜Nuada, god of war and warriors (neutral)
text | 6｜Zivilyn, god of wisdom (neutral)
text | 7｜Arawn, god of life and death (neutral evil)
text | 8｜Hecate, god of magic and moons (chaotic evil)
text | 9｜Celestian, god of stars and wanderers (neutral)
text | 10｜Ptah, god of knowledge and secrets (lawful neutral)

title: Athlete
contents: bullet | Skill Proficiencies: Acrobatics, Athletics
bullet | Languages: One of your choice
bullet | Tool Proficiencies: Vehicles (land)
bullet | Equipment: A bronze discus or leather ball, a lucky charm or past trophy, a set of traveler's clothes, and a pouch containing 10 gp

description | Feature: Echoes of Victory | You have attracted admiration among spectators, fellow athletes, and trainers in the region that hosted your past athletic victories. When visiting any settlement within 100 miles of where you grew up, there is a 50 percent chance you can find someone there who admires you and is willing to provide information or temporary shelter.

text | Between adventures, you might compete in athletic events sufficient enough to maintain a comfortable lifestyle, as per the "Practicing a Profession" downtime activity in chapter 8 of the Player's Handbook.

description | Favored Event | While many athletes practice various games and events, most excel at a single form of competition. Roll or choose from the options in the Favored Event table to determine the athletic event in which you excel.
text | Favored Event
text | d8｜Favored Event
text | 1｜Marathon
text | 2｜Long-distance running
text | 3｜Wrestling
text | 4｜Boxing
text | 5｜Chariot or horse race
text | 6｜Pankration (mixed unarmed combat)
text | 7｜Hoplite race (racing in full armor with a unit)
text | 8｜Pentathlon (running, long jump, discus, javelin, wrestling)

description | Suggested Characteristics | Competition can forge strong bonds between teammates and rivals or ignite bitter feuds that burn outside the arena. Athletes often apply lessons from their training to their lives in general.
text | Athlete Personality Traits
text | d8｜Personality Trait
text | 1｜I feel most at peace during physical exertion, be it exercise or battle.
text | 2｜I don't like to sit idle.
text | 3｜I have a daily exercise routine that I refuse to break.
text | 4｜Obstacles exist to be overcome.
text | 5｜When I see others struggling, I offer to help.
text | 6｜I love to trade banter and gibes.
text | 7｜Anything worth doing is worth doing best.
text | 8｜I get irritated if people praise someone else and not me.
text | Athlete Ideals
text | d6｜Ideal
text | 1｜Competition. I strive to test myself in all things. (Chaotic)
text | 2｜Triumph. The best part of winning is seeing my rivals brought low. (Evil)
text | 3｜Camaraderie. The strongest bonds are forged through struggle. (Good)
text | 4｜People. I strive to inspire my spectators. (Neutral)
text | 5｜Tradition. Every game has rules, and the playing field must be level. (Lawful)
text | 6｜Growth. Lessons hide in victory and defeat. (Any)
text | Athlete Bonds
text | d6｜Bond
text | 1｜My teammates are my family.
text | 2｜I will overcome a rival and prove myself their better.
text | 3｜My mistake got someone hurt. I'll never make that mistake again.
text | 4｜I will be the best for the honor and glory of my home.
text | 5｜The person who trained me is the most important person in my world.
text | 6｜I strive to live up to a specific hero's example.
text | Athlete Flaws
text | d6｜Flaw
text | 1｜I indulge in a habit that threatens my reputation or my health.
text | 2｜I'll do absolutely anything to win.
text | 3｜I ignore anyone who doesn't compete and anyone who loses to me.
text | 4｜I have lingering pain from old injuries.
text | 5｜Any defeat or failure on my part is because my opponent cheated.
text | 6｜I must be the captain of any group I join.

title: Augen Trust (Spy)
contents: bullet | Skill Proficiencies: Deception, Stealth
bullet | Tool Proficiencies: One type of gaming set, thieves' tools
bullet | Equipment: A crowbar, a set of dark common clothes including a hood, and a belt pouch containing 15 gp

description | Feature: Spy Contact | You have a reliable and trustworthy contact who acts as your liaison to a network of other spies. You know how to get messages to and from your contact, even over great distances; specifically, you know the local messengers, corrupt caravan masters, and seedy sailors who can deliver messages for you.

description | Specialty | There are many kinds of criminals, and within a thieves' guild or similar criminal organization, individual members have particular specialties. Even criminals who operate outside of such organizations have strong preferences for certain kinds of crimes over others. Choose the role you played in your criminal life, or roll on the table below.
text | d8｜Specialty
text | 1｜Blackmailer
text | 2｜Burglar
text | 3｜Enforcer
text | 4｜Fence
text | 5｜Highway robber
text | 6｜Hired killer
text | 7｜Pickpocket
text | 8｜Smuggler

description | Suggested Characteristics | Criminals might seem like villains on the surface, and many of them are villainous to the core. But some have an abundance of endearing, if not redeeming, characteristics. There might be honor among thieves, but criminals rarely show any respect for law or authority.
text | d8｜Personality Trait
text | 1｜I always have a plan for when things go wrong.
text | 2｜I am always calm, no matter what the situation. I never raise my voice or let my emotions control me.
text | 3｜The first thing I do in a new place is note the locations of everything valuable—or where such things could be hidden.
text | 4｜I would rather make a new friend than a new enemy.
text | 5｜I am incredibly slow to trust. Those who seem the fairest often have the most to hide.
text | 6｜I don't pay attention to the risks in a situation. Never tell me the odds.
text | 7｜The best way to get me to do something is to tell me I can't do it.
text | 8｜I blow up at the slightest insult.
text | d6｜Ideal
text | 1｜Honor. I don't steal from others in the trade. (Lawful)
text | 2｜Freedom. Chains are meant to be broken, as are those who would forge them. (Chaotic)
text | 3｜Charity. I steal from the wealthy so that I can help people in need. (Good)
text | 4｜Greed. I will do whatever it takes to become wealthy. (Evil)
text | 5｜People. I'm loyal to my friends, not to any ideals, and everyone else can take a trip down the Styx for all I care. (Neutral)
text | 6｜Redemption. There's a spark of good in everyone. (Good)
text | d6｜Bond
text | 1｜I'm trying to pay off an old debt I owe to a generous benefactor.
text | 2｜My ill-gotten gains go to support my family.
text | 3｜Something important was taken from me, and I aim to steal it back.
text | 4｜I will become the greatest thief that ever lived.
text | 5｜I'm guilty of a terrible crime. I hope I can redeem myself for it.
text | 6｜Someone I loved died because of a mistake I made. That will never happen again.
text | d6｜Flaw
text | 1｜When I see something valuable, I can't think about anything but how to steal it.
text | 2｜When faced with a choice between money and my friends, I usually choose the money.
text | 3｜If there's a plan, I'll forget it. If I don't forget it, I'll ignore it.
text | 4｜I have a 'tell' that reveals when I'm lying.
text | 5｜I turn tail and run when things look bad.
text | 6｜An innocent person is in prison for a crime that I committed. I'm okay with that.

title: Azorius Functionary
contents: bullet | Skill Proficiencies: Insight, Intimidation
bullet | Languages: Two of your choice

bullet | Equipment: An Azorius insignia, a scroll containing the text of a law important to you, a bottle of blue ink, a pen, a set of fine clothes, and a belt pouch containing 10 gp (Azorius-minted 1-zino coins)

description | Feature: Legal Authority | You have the authority to enforce the laws of Ravnica, and that status inspires a certain amount of respect and even fear in the populace. People mind their manners in your presence and avoid drawing your attention; they assume you have the right to be wherever you are. Showing your Azorius insignia gets you an audience with anyone you want to talk to (though it might cause more problems than it solves when you're dealing with incorrigible lawbreakers). If you abuse this privilege, though, you can get in serious trouble with your superiors and even be stripped of your position.
description | Azorius Guild Spells | Prerequisite: Spellcasting or Pact Magic class feature

text | For you, the spells on the Azorius Guild Spells table are added to the spell list of your spellcasting class. (If you are a multiclass character with multiple spell lists, these spells are added to all of them.)
text | Azorius Guild Spells
text | Spell Level｜Spells
text | Cantrip｜friends, message
text | 1st｜command, ensnaring strike
text | 2nd｜arcane lock, calm emotions, hold person
text | 3rd｜clairvoyance, counterspell
text | 4th｜compulsion, divination
text | 5th｜dominate person

text | Your magic often takes the form of blue or golden runes floating and glowing in the air in circular patterns or of shimmering azure barriers of magical energy. If you cast ensnaring strike, for example, the vines created by the spell might appear as rune-inscribed glowing bands that wrap around the target and hold it in place.

description | Suggested Characteristics | Members of the Azorius Senate tend toward a demeanor of cold dignity and a pragmatic, orderly nature. Steeped in the law as they are, their ideals and priorities revolve around legal issues.
text | Personality Traits
text | d8｜Trait
text | 1｜I try never to let my judgment become clouded by emotion.
text | 2｜I have infinite patience with the dolts and boors I'm forced to deal with every day.
text | 3｜When I give an order, I expect it to be obeyed.
text | 4｜I just want things the way I like them: neat, orderly, and clean.
text | 5｜No wrongdoing can escape my watchful gaze.
text | 6｜I always say exactly what I mean, no matter how many words it takes to communicate the particular nuance I am attempting to convey.
text | 7｜I'm very literal and don't appreciate metaphor or sarcasm.
text | 8｜I never change my mind once it's made up.
text | Ideals
text | d6｜Ideal
text | 1｜Guild. My guild is all that really matters. (Any)
text | 2｜Order. The law is meant to ensure that the gears of society turn smoothly and quietly. (Lawful)
text | 3｜Peace. The ultimate object of the law is to remove violence from society. (Good)
text | 4｜Compliance. Coercion is a fine way of ensuring that the laws are obeyed. (Lawful)
text | 5｜Legislation. The law embodies excellence in its precision and detail. (Lawful)
text | 6｜Punishment. A public display of consequences is an excellent deterrent for other criminals. (Evil)
text | Bonds
text | d6｜Bond
text | 1｜I am beholden to an Azorius arrester who captured the criminal who killed my parents, saving me from the same fate.
text | 2｜I hope one day to write the laws, not just enforce them.
text | 3｜I tried and failed to prevent a murder, and I have sworn to find and arrest the perpetrator.
text | 4｜I successfully prevented a murder, and the would-be perpetrator wants me dead.
text | 5｜One of my parents was prominent in the guild, and I resent constantly being compared to that standard.
text | 6｜I've modeled my career after a highly respected lawmage or arrester, but I fear that my role model might be involved in something illegal.
text | Flaws
text | d6｜Flaw
text | 1｜I'm unable to distinguish between the letter and the spirit of the law.
text | 2｜I seem like a harsh judge to others, but I judge myself most harshly of all.
text | 3｜I have a secret, illegal vice.
text | 4｜I was traumatized by witnessing a crime as a child.
text | 5｜I'm incapable of deception.
text | 6｜I wish I had joined the Boros, but I fear they'd never accept me.

description | Contacts | The Azorius Senate is a sprawling bureaucracy, and people in a variety of positions throughout the guild can pull strings to make things happen. Because of the guild's role in making and enforcing laws for the entire city, your place in the Azorius can easily bring you into contact with members of other guilds, for good or ill.
text | Roll twice on the Azorius Contacts table (for an ally and a rival) and once on the Non-Azorius Contacts table.
text | Azorius Contacts
text | d8｜Contact
text | 1｜As a teenager, I was a page for a prominent judge.
text | 2｜One of my childhood friends is now a precognitive mage in service of the guild.
text | 3｜I joined the Azorius hoping to impress an arrester whom I admire.
text | 4｜My former mentor is now a warden at Udzec, the new Azorius prison.
text | 5｜I was second best at everything in my legal training, and now I work with the person who was always just a little bit better.
text | 6｜A good friend was promoted into work they can't tell me about.
text | 7｜I know a homunculus in the halls of New Prahv who can get things done behind the scenes.
text | 8｜I was once summoned to the presence of Supreme Judge Isperia, the guildmaster of the Azorius, who complimented me on my work.
text | Non-Azorius Contacts
text | d10｜Contact
text | 1｜Roll an additional Azorius contact; you can decide if the contact is an ally or a rival.
text | 2｜The person who recruited me into the Azorius left and joined the Boros.
text | 3｜I have a friendship with a Dimir agent who sometimes funnels me secrets about Azorius activities.
text | 4｜A Golgari spore druid would love to see me slip up and break the law.
text | 5｜A lesser Gruul chieftain seems to think I could be useful.
text | 6｜The black sheep of my family is putting their maniacal genius to use in the Izzet.
text | 7｜I'm friends with an Orzhov advokist; we compare notes on different forms of law magic.
text | 8｜I was ridiculed once in a Rakdos performance; the performer was impressed with my good humor about it and now does me occasional favors.
text | 9｜I have a fanatical Selesnya cousin who keeps trying to recruit me and everyone else in the family.
text | 10｜While growing up, I was bullied by a brat who's now a hybrid in the Simic Combine.

description | How Do I Fit In? | As a member of the Azorius Senate, you are probably engaged in the work of law enforcement (even if your background involved the legislative or judicial aspects of the senate's activities). Legislative aides and judges' clerks find little reason to venture beyond the Azorius guildhalls, but soldiers and lawmages patrol the streets daily.

text | An Azorius soldier or lawmage is a force for order, charged with fighting crime on the streets—and in the halls of power. You might spend your time foiling thefts, putting a stop to Orzhov extortion, rooting out Dimir spies, or hunting down Golgari assassins. Perhaps you take your orders from a precognitive mage (or you are one yourself) who receives unpredictable and cryptic visions of future crimes that you and your allies must try to prevent.

title: Baldur's Gate Acolyte
contents: bullet | Skill Proficiencies: Insight, Religion
bullet | Languages: Two of your choice

bullet | Equipment: A holy symbol (a gift to you when you entered the priesthood), a prayer book or prayer wheel, 5 sticks of incense, vestments, a set of common clothes, and a belt pouch containing 15 gp

description | Feature: Shelter of the Faithful | As an acolyte, you command the respect of those who share your faith, and you can perform the religious ceremonies of your deity. You and your adventuring companions can expect to receive free healing and care at a temple, shrine, or other established presence of your faith, though you must provide any material components needed for spells. Those who share your religion will support you (but only you) at a modest lifestyle.

text | You might also have ties to a specific temple dedicated to your chosen deity or pantheon, and you have a residence there. This could be the temple where you used to serve, if you remain on good terms with it, or a temple where you have found a new home. While near your temple, you can call upon the priests for assistance, provided the assistance you ask for is not hazardous and you remain in good standing with your temple.

description | Baldur's Gate Feature: Religious Community | The effects of a Baldur's Gate feature can be used only while the character is in Baldur's Gate—though, at the DM's discretion, they might have applicable effects in situations similar to those in Baldur's Gate.

text | You're tightly connected with the religious community of Baldur's Gate. You know if a deity has a following in the city and any places that faith openly congregates and the neighborhoods those faithful typically inhabit. While this isn't remarkable for most of the city's larger faiths, keeping track of the hundreds of religions newcomers bring with them is no mean feat.

description | Suggested Characteristics | Acolytes are shaped by their experience in temples or other religious communities. Their study of the history and tenets of their faith and their relationships to temples, shrines, or hierarchies affect their mannerisms and ideals. Their flaws might be some hidden hypocrisy or heretical idea, or an ideal or bond taken to an extreme.
text | d8｜Personality Trait
text | 1｜I idolize a particular hero of my faith, and constantly refer to that person's deeds and example.
text | 2｜I can find common ground between the fiercest enemies, empathizing with them and always working toward peace.
text | 3｜I see omens in every event and action. The gods try to speak to us, we just need to listen.
text | 4｜Nothing can shake my optimistic attitude.
text | 5｜I quote (or misquote) sacred texts and proverbs in almost every situation.
text | 6｜I am tolerant (or intolerant) of other faiths and respect (or condemn) the worship of other gods.
text | 7｜I've enjoyed fine food, drink, and high society among my temple's elite. Rough living grates on me.
text | 8｜I've spent so long in the temple that I have little practical experience dealing with people in the outside world.
text | d6｜Ideal
text | 1｜Tradition. The ancient traditions of worship and sacrifice must be preserved and upheld. (Lawful)
text | 2｜Charity. I always try to help those in need, no matter what the personal cost. (Good)
text | 3｜Change. We must help bring about the changes the gods are constantly working in the world. (Chaotic)
text | 4｜Power. I hope to one day rise to the top of my faith's religious hierarchy. (Lawful)
text | 5｜Faith. I trust that my deity will guide my actions. I have faith that if I work hard, things will go well. (Lawful)
text | 6｜Aspiration. I seek to prove myself worthy of my god's favor by matching my actions against his or her teachings. (Any)
text | d6｜Bond
text | 1｜I would die to recover an ancient relic of my faith that was lost long ago.
text | 2｜I will someday get revenge on the corrupt temple hierarchy who branded me a heretic.
text | 3｜I owe my life to the priest who took me in when my parents died.
text | 4｜Everything I do is for the common people.
text | 5｜I will do anything to protect the temple where I served.
text | 6｜I seek to preserve a sacred text that my enemies consider heretical and seek to destroy.
text | d6｜Flaw
text | 1｜I judge others harshly, and myself even more severely.
text | 2｜I put too much trust in those who wield power within my temple's hierarchy.
text | 3｜My piety sometimes leads me to blindly trust those that profess faith in my god.
text | 4｜I am inflexible in my thinking.
text | 5｜I am suspicious of strangers and expect the worst of them.
text | 6｜Once I pick a goal, I become obsessed with it to the detriment of everything else in my life.

title: Baldur's Gate Charlatan
contents: bullet | Skill Proficiencies: Deception, Sleight of Hand
bullet | Tool Proficiencies: Disguise kit, Forgery kit

bullet | Equipment: A set of fine clothes, a disguise kit, tools of the con of your choice (ten stoppered bottles filled with colored liquid, a set of weighted dice, a deck of marked cards, or a signet ring of an imaginary duke), and a belt pouch containing 15 gp

description | Feature: False Identity | You have created a second identity that includes documentation, established acquaintances, and disguises that allow you to assume that persona. Additionally, you can forge documents including official papers and personal letters, as long as you have seen an example of the kind of document or the handwriting you are trying to copy.

description | Baldur's Gate Feature: Long-Lost Heir | The effects of a Baldur's Gate feature can be used only while the character is in Baldur's Gate—though, at the DM's discretion, they might have applicable effects in situations similar to those in Baldur's Gate.

text | You're well-versed in the mannerisms and idiosyncrasies of Baldurian patriars and other nobles, imitating them smoothly enough to convince even the snootiest family heads of your authenticity. You're skilled at posing as the long-lost heir to some imaginary or extinguished patriar lineage.

text | Because of your skill in passing yourself off as a patriar, you have a Watch token that allows you alone into the Upper City of Baldur's Gate. You might be able to bluff others through with you, or even convince members of the Watch that you're a patriar. However, any true test of your authenticity is likely to reveal your deception.
description | Favorite Schemes | Every charlatan has an angle he or she uses in preference to other schemes. Choose a favorite scam or roll on the table below.
text | d6｜Scam
text | 1｜I cheat at games of chance.
text | 2｜I shave coins or forge documents.
text | 3｜I insinuate myself into people's lives to prey on their weakness and secure their fortunes.
text | 4｜I put on new identities like clothes.
text | 5｜I run sleight-of-hand cons on street corners.
text | 6｜I convince people that worthless junk is worth their hard-earned money.

description | Suggested Characteristics | Charlatans are colorful characters who conceal their true selves behind the masks they construct. They reflect what people want to see, what they want to believe, and how they see the world. But their true selves are sometimes plagued by an uneasy conscience, an old enemy, or deep-seated trust issues.
text | d8｜Personality Trait
text | 1｜I fall in and out of love easily, and am always pursuing someone.
text | 2｜I have a joke for every occasion, especially occasions where humor is inappropriate.
text | 3｜Flattery is my preferred trick for getting what I want.
text | 4｜I'm a born gambler who can't resist taking a risk for a potential payoff.
text | 5｜I lie about almost everything, even when there's no reason to.
text | 6｜Sarcasm and insults are my weapons of choice.
text | 7｜I keep multiple holy symbols on me and invoke whatever deity might come in useful at any given moment.
text | 8｜I pocket anything I see that might have some value.
text | d6｜Ideal
text | 1｜Independence. I am a free spirit—no one tells me what to do. (Chaotic)
text | 2｜Fairness. I never target people who can't afford to lose a few coins. (Lawful)
text | 3｜Charity. I distribute the money I acquire to the people who really need it. (Good)
text | 4｜Creativity. I never run the same con twice. (Chaotic)
text | 5｜Friendship. Material goods come and go. Bonds of friendship last forever. (Good)
text | 6｜Aspiration. I'm determined to make something of myself. (Any)
text | d6｜Bond
text | 1｜I fleeced the wrong person and must work to ensure that this individual never crosses paths with me or those I care about.
text | 2｜I owe everything to my mentor—a horrible person who's probably rotting in jail somewhere.
text | 3｜Somewhere out there, I have a child who doesn't know me. I'm making the world better for him or her.
text | 4｜I come from a noble family, and one day I'll reclaim my lands and title from those who stole them from me.
text | 5｜A powerful person killed someone I love. Some day soon, I'll have my revenge.
text | 6｜I swindled and ruined a person who didn't deserve it. I seek to atone for my misdeeds but might never be able to forgive myself.
text | d6｜Flaw
text | 1｜I can't resist a pretty face.
text | 2｜I'm always in debt. I spend my ill-gotten gains on decadent luxuries faster than I bring them in.
text | 3｜I'm convinced that no one could ever fool me the way I fool others.
text | 4｜I'm too greedy for my own good. I can't resist taking a risk if there's money involved.
text | 5｜I can't resist swindling people who are more powerful than me.
text | 6｜I hate to admit it and will hate myself for it, but I'll run and preserve my own hide if the going gets tough.

title: Baldur's Gate Criminal
contents: bullet | Skill Proficiencies: Deception, Stealth
bullet | Tool Proficiencies: One type of gaming set, thieves' tools
bullet | Equipment: A crowbar, a set of dark common clothes including a hood, and a belt pouch containing 15 gp

description | Feature: Criminal Contact | You have a reliable and trustworthy contact who acts as your liaison to a network of other criminals. You know how to get messages to and from your contact, even over great distances; specifically, you know the local messengers, corrupt caravan masters, and seedy sailors who can deliver messages for you.

description | Baldur's Gate Feature: Criminal Connections | The effects of a Baldur's Gate feature can be used only while the character is in Baldur's Gate—though, at the DM's discretion, they might have applicable effects in situations similar to those in Baldur's Gate.

text | In Baldur's Gate, crime is just another business. As a result, you can arrange a meeting with a low-ranking operative of nearly any business, patriar family, crew, government institution, or—certainly—the Guild. This operative will hear you out and, at their discretion, take your information or request up their chain of command. These meetings almost always occur in shady venues.
description | Criminal Origins | Criminals are pervasive in Baldur's Gate. If you wish, you may roll on the Criminal Origins table for an event that began your life of crime.
text | Criminal Origins
text | d8｜Origin

text | 1｜You crippled a Guild kingpin's cousin without realizing the connection. You got the Guild to back off demands for your death by offering to make amends by working for the criminals, but even so the kingpin still plots a personal revenge.

text | 2｜The Guild took over your family business, ran it into the ground, and burned the building for insurance money. You were driven into crime yourself, but you'll never work for the Guild. You take special joy in hitting its targets first, tipping off its con victims and otherwise frustrating its schemes.

text | 3｜It's always been about money. You're not paid what you're worth, working for someone who has more than they deserve. But the Guild offered you a way to fix that. You keep doing what you've always done—guard work, dock labor, business accounting—but what you learn you pass on to the Guild.

text | 4｜The inequality of Baldur's Gate has driven you to take matters into your own hands. You steal from patriars and rich Lower City residents, funneling the money through charitable fronts to help the needy.

text | 5｜You got into crime as a bored patriar looking for excitement. Your family has no idea of your activities, and neither does the Guild. If either of them ever finds out, your life as you know it will be over.
text | 6｜A close friend or relative joined the Guild and vanished mysteriously. You've worked your way into the lower ranks hoping to find out what happened to them.

text | 7｜You've always wanted to be a member of the Guild. As a child, you looked up to the Guild members' swagger, their flashy dress, and their competence, which all marked them as different from the other adults you knew. As soon as you could, you joined the organization.

text | 8｜To you, this is just a way to earn a living. You go to work, do what needs to be done, and get paid. Anyone who pursues crime for thrill-seeking, to strike back at unjust authorities, or anything else are amateurs, and they're liable to get you arrested or killed with their idiocy.

description | Specialty | There are many kinds of criminals, and within a thieves' guild or similar criminal organization, individual members have particular specialties. Even criminals who operate outside of such organizations have strong preferences for certain kinds of crimes over others. Choose the role you played in your criminal life, or roll on the table below.
text | d8｜Specialty
text | 1｜Blackmailer
text | 2｜Burglar
text | 3｜Enforcer
text | 4｜Fence
text | 5｜Highway robber
text | 6｜Hired killer
text | 7｜Pickpocket
text | 8｜Smuggler

description | Suggested Characteristics | Criminals might seem like villains on the surface, and many of them are villainous to the core. But some have an abundance of endearing, if not redeeming, characteristics. There might be honor among thieves, but criminals rarely show any respect for law or authority.
text | d8｜Personality Trait
text | 1｜I always have a plan for when things go wrong.
text | 2｜I am always calm, no matter what the situation. I never raise my voice or let my emotions control me.
text | 3｜The first thing I do in a new place is note the locations of everything valuable—or where such things could be hidden.
text | 4｜I would rather make a new friend than a new enemy.
text | 5｜I am incredibly slow to trust. Those who seem the fairest often have the most to hide.
text | 6｜I don't pay attention to the risks in a situation. Never tell me the odds.
text | 7｜The best way to get me to do something is to tell me I can't do it.
text | 8｜I blow up at the slightest insult.
text | d6｜Ideal
text | 1｜Honor. I don't steal from others in the trade. (Lawful)
text | 2｜Freedom. Chains are meant to be broken, as are those who would forge them. (Chaotic)
text | 3｜Charity. I steal from the wealthy so that I can help people in need. (Good)
text | 4｜Greed. I will do whatever it takes to become wealthy. (Evil)
text | 5｜People. I'm loyal to my friends, not to any ideals, and everyone else can take a trip down the Styx for all I care. (Neutral)
text | 6｜Redemption. There's a spark of good in everyone. (Good)
text | d6｜Bond
text | 1｜I'm trying to pay off an old debt I owe to a generous benefactor.
text | 2｜My ill-gotten gains go to support my family.
text | 3｜Something important was taken from me, and I aim to steal it back.
text | 4｜I will become the greatest thief that ever lived.
text | 5｜I'm guilty of a terrible crime. I hope I can redeem myself for it.
text | 6｜Someone I loved died because of a mistake I made. That will never happen again.
text | d6｜Flaw
text | 1｜When I see something valuable, I can't think about anything but how to steal it.
text | 2｜When faced with a choice between money and my friends, I usually choose the money.
text | 3｜If there's a plan, I'll forget it. If I don't forget it, I'll ignore it.
text | 4｜I have a 'tell' that reveals when I'm lying.
text | 5｜I turn tail and run when things look bad.
text | 6｜An innocent person is in prison for a crime that I committed. I'm okay with that.

title: Baldur's Gate Entertainer
contents: bullet | Skill Proficiencies: Acrobatics, Performance
bullet | Tool Proficiencies: Disguise kit, one type of musical instrument
bullet | Equipment: A musical instrument (one of your choice), the favor of an admirer (love letter, lock of hair, or trinket), costume clothes, and a belt pouch containing 15 gp

description | Feature: By Popular Demand | You can always find a place to perform, usually in an inn or tavern but possibly with a circus, at a theater, or even in a noble's court. At such a place, you receive free lodging and food of a modest or comfortable standard (depending on the quality of the establishment), as long as you perform each night. In addition, your performance makes you something of a local figure. When strangers recognize you in a town where you have performed, they typically take a liking to you.

description | Baldur's Gate Feature: Backstage Pass | The effects of a Baldur's Gate feature can be used only while the character is in Baldur's Gate—though, at the DM's discretion, they might have applicable effects in situations similar to those in Baldur's Gate.

text | You've learned that most of the real business of entertainment (or any other venture) happens behind the scenes. It's easy for you to case what sorts of audiences attend what venue—like how toughs gather at the Blushing Mermaid or how brash patriars congregate at the Helm and Cloak. After a successful performance, you may meet an enthusiastic member of the crowd—someone of an occupation or social class that frequents the establishment. This contact is delighted to talk with you, and to listen.

description | Specialty | A good entertainer is versatile, spicing up every performance with a variety of different routines. Choose one to three routines or roll on the table below to define your expertise as an entertainer.
text | d10｜Routines
text | 1｜Actor
text | 2｜Dancer
text | 3｜Fire-eater
text | 4｜Jester
text | 5｜Juggler
text | 6｜Instrumentalist
text | 7｜Poet
text | 8｜Singer
text | 9｜Storyteller
text | 10｜Tumbler

description | Suggested Characteristics | Successful entertainers have to be able to capture and hold an audience's attention, so they tend to have flamboyant or forceful personalities. They're inclined toward the romantic and often cling to high-minded ideals about the practice of art and the appreciation of beauty.
text | d8｜Personality Trait
text | 1｜I know a story relevant to almost every situation.
text | 2｜Whenever I come to a new place, I collect local rumors and spread gossip.
text | 3｜I'm a hopeless romantic, always searching for that "special someone".
text | 4｜Nobody stays angry at me or around me for long, since I can defuse any amount of tension.
text | 5｜I love a good insult, even one directed at me.
text | 6｜I get bitter if I'm not the center of attention.
text | 7｜I'll settle for nothing less than perfection.
text | 8｜I change my mood or my mind as quickly as I change key in a song.
text | d6｜Ideal
text | 1｜Beauty. When I perform, I make the world better than it was. (Good)
text | 2｜Tradition. The stories, legends, and songs of the past must never be forgotten, for they teach us who we are. (Lawful)
text | 3｜Creativity. The world is in need of new ideas and bold action. (Chaotic)
text | 4｜Greed. I'm only in it for the money and fame. (Evil)
text | 5｜People. I like seeing the smiles on people's faces when I perform. That's all that matters. (Neutral)
text | 6｜Honesty. Art should reflect the soul; it should come from within and reveal who we really are. (Any)
text | d6｜Bond
text | 1｜My instrument is my most treasured possession, and it reminds me of someone I love.
text | 2｜Someone stole my precious instrument, and someday I'll get it back.
text | 3｜I want to be famous, whatever it takes.
text | 4｜I idolize a hero of the old tales and measure my deeds against that person's.
text | 5｜I will do anything to prove myself superior to my hated rival.
text | 6｜I would do anything for the other members of my old troupe.
text | d6｜Flaw
text | 1｜I'll do anything to win fame and renown.
text | 2｜I'm a sucker for a pretty face.
text | 3｜A scandal prevents me from ever going home again. That kind of trouble seems to follow me around.
text | 4｜I once satirized a noble who still wants my head. It was a mistake that I will likely repeat.
text | 5｜I have trouble keeping my true feelings hidden. My sharp tongue lands me in trouble.
text | 6｜Despite my best efforts, I am unreliable to my friends.

title: Baldur's Gate Folk Hero
contents: bullet | Skill Proficiencies: Animal Handling, Survival
bullet | Tool Proficiencies: One type of artisan's tools, vehicles (land)
bullet | Equipment: A set of artisan's tools (one of your choice), a shovel, an iron pot, a set of common clothes, and a belt pouch containing 10 gp

description | Feature: Rustic Hospitality | Since you come from the ranks of the common folk, you fit in among them with ease. You can find a place to hide, rest, or recuperate among other commoners, unless you have shown yourself to be a danger to them. They will shield you from the law or anyone else searching for you, though they will not risk their lives for you.

description | Baldur's Gate Feature: Social Vengeance | The effects of a Baldur's Gate feature can be used only while the character is in Baldur's Gate—though, at the DM's discretion, they might have applicable effects in situations similar to those in Baldur's Gate.

text | You've lived your entire life in the Lower or Outer City of Baldur's Gate. You grew up seeing arrogant patriars flaunt their wealth while your hardworking neighbors struggled. As a result, you know how eager commoners in Baldur's Gate are to see any patriar get what they deserve. While in a busy part of the Lower City or Outer City of Baldur's Gate, you can spend 2d10 minutes to convince 1d6 commoners to perform a non-illegal act that inconveniences a member of the Watch or Flaming Fist, a patriar, or some other wealthy looking individual.

description | Folk Hero Origins | Folk heroes might rise from a variety of circumstances, or their origins might be a secret as they do their work anonymously. If you wish, you may roll on the Folk Hero Origins table for an event that started you down your heroic path.
text | Folk Hero Origins
text | d6｜Origin
text | 1｜You helped get healing for a sick child. Now the sick come to you, knowing you'll help them find a way to salvation.

text | 2｜You helped break a Guild protection racket afflicting a community of immigrants in the Outer City. Now, you can't travel through that part of the city without your dozen adopted grandparents inviting you in for a meal.

text | 3｜Seeing a lost patriar after dark in the Outer City, you guided the wayward noble through back streets to safety. The patriar repaid your help by paying for improved roofs and lamps in your neighborhood, causing the entire community to celebrate your deed.

text | 4｜Fueled by alcohol, you faced down a carrion crawler that slunk out of the sewer, knocking it out with a single punch. Since then, however, the ale you once credited with your heroism has drowned it, and even your most patient admirers are losing hope. You're hoping for one last chance to win back the goodwill you've drunk away.
text | 5｜You once defeated a raging bugbear with a hand mirror, a mounted deer's head, and two kicks to the groin. Later, you and the bugbear became friends.
text | 6｜Last winter, you dove into the frigid river to haul out a foundering fishing boat with your bare hands, saving all aboard. Now, everyone on the docks knows your name.

description | Specialty | You previously pursued a simple profession among the peasantry, perhaps as a farmer, miner, servant, shepherd, woodcutter, or gravedigger. But something happened that set you on a different path and marked you for greater things. Choose or randomly determine a defining event that marked you as a hero of the people.
text | d10｜Defining Event
text | 1｜I stood up to a tyrant's agents.
text | 2｜I saved people during a natural disaster.
text | 3｜I stood alone against a terrible monster.
text | 4｜I stole from a corrupt merchant to help the poor.
text | 5｜I led a militia to fight off an invading army.
text | 6｜I broke into a tyrant's castle and stole weapons to arm the people.
text | 7｜I trained the peasantry to use farming implements as weapons against a tyrant's soldiers.
text | 8｜A lord rescinded an unpopular decree after I led a symbolic act of protest against it.
text | 9｜A celestial, fey, or similar creature gave me a blessing or revealed my secret origin.
text | 10｜Recruited into a lord's army, I rose to leadership and was commended for my heroism.

description | Suggested Characteristics | A folk hero is one of the common people, for better or for worse. Most folk heroes look on their humble origins as a virtue, not a shortcoming, and their home communities remain very important to them.
text | d8｜Personality Trait
text | 1｜I judge people by their actions, not their words.
text | 2｜If someone is in trouble, I'm always ready to lend help.
text | 3｜When I set my mind to something, I follow through no matter what gets in my way.
text | 4｜I have a strong sense of fair play and always try to find the most equitable solution to arguments.
text | 5｜I'm confident in my own abilities and do what I can to instill confidence in others.
text | 6｜Thinking is for other people. I prefer action.
text | 7｜I misuse long words in an attempt to sound smarter.
text | 8｜I get bored easily. When am I going to get on with my destiny?
text | d6｜Ideal
text | 1｜Respect. People deserve to be treated with dignity and respect. (Good)
text | 2｜Fairness. No one should get preferential treatment before the law, and no one is above the law. (Lawful)
text | 3｜Freedom. Tyrants must not be allowed to oppress the people. (Chaotic)
text | 4｜Might. If I become strong, I can take what I want—what I deserve. (Evil)
text | 5｜Sincerity. There's no good in pretending to be something I'm not. (Neutral)
text | 6｜Destiny. Nothing and no one can steer me away from my higher calling. (Any)
text | d6｜Bond
text | 1｜I have a family, but I have no idea where they are. One day, I hope to see them again.
text | 2｜I worked the land, I love the land, and I will protect the land.
text | 3｜A proud noble once gave me a horrible beating, and I will take my revenge on any bully I encounter.
text | 4｜My tools are symbols of my past life, and I carry them so that I will never forget my roots.
text | 5｜I protect those who cannot protect themselves.
text | 6｜I wish my childhood sweetheart had come with me to pursue my destiny.
text | d6｜Flaw
text | 1｜The tyrant who rules my land will stop at nothing to see me killed.
text | 2｜I'm convinced of the significance of my destiny, and blind to my shortcomings and the risk of failure.
text | 3｜The people who knew me when I was young know my shameful secret, so I can never go home again.
text | 4｜I have a weakness for the vices of the city, especially hard drink.
text | 5｜Secretly, I believe that things would be better if I were a tyrant lording over the land.
text | 6｜I have trouble trusting in my allies.

title: Baldur's Gate Guild Artisan
contents: bullet | Skill Proficiencies: Insight, Persuasion
bullet | Tool Proficiencies: One type of artisan's tools
bullet | Languages: One of your choice
bullet | Equipment: A set of artisan's tools (one of your choice), a letter of introduction from your guild, a set of traveler's clothes, and a belt pouch containing 15 gp

description | Feature: Guild Membership | As an established and respected member of a guild, you can rely on certain benefits that membership provides. Your fellow guild members will provide you with lodging and food if necessary, and pay for your funeral if needed. In some cities and towns, a guildhall offers a central place to meet other members of your profession, which can be a good place to meet potential patrons, allies, or hirelings.

text | Guilds often wield tremendous political power. If you are accused of a crime, your guild will support you if a good case can be made for your innocence or the crime is justifiable. You can also gain access to powerful political figures through the guild, if you are a member in good standing. Such connections might require the donation of money or magic items to the guild's coffers.
text | You must pay dues of 5 gp per month to the guild. If you miss payments, you must make up back dues to remain in the guild's good graces.

description | Baldur's Gate Feature: Professional Courtesy | The effects of a Baldur's Gate feature can be used only while the character is in Baldur's Gate—though, at the DM's discretion, they might have applicable effects in situations similar to those in Baldur's Gate.

text | You're familiar with the city's crews, their territories, and inter-crew politics. Choose one of the three districts of Baldur's Gate: the Upper City, the Lower City, or the Outer City. This is the district where you conduct most of your business. Whenever you need information about something in one of that district's neighborhoods, you can seek out crew members in that area and learn the local gossip. You can also gain unimpeded entry to nearly any bank, guild hall, place of business, workhouse, or crew meeting place in your district.

description | Specialty | Guilds are generally found in cities large enough to support several artisans practicing the same trade. However, your guild might instead be a loose network of artisans who each work in a different village within a larger realm. Work with your DM to determine the nature of your guild. You can select your guild business from the Guild Business table or roll randomly.
text | d20｜Guild Business
text | 1｜Alchemists and apothecaries
text | 2｜Armorers, locksmiths, and finesmiths
text | 3｜Brewers, distillers, and vintners
text | 4｜Calligraphers, scribes, and scriveners
text | 5｜Carpenters, roofers, and plasterers
text | 6｜Cartographers, surveyors, and chart-makers
text | 7｜Cobblers and shoemakers
text | 8｜Cooks and bakers
text | 9｜Glassblowers and glaziers
text | 10｜Jewelers and gemcutters
text | 11｜Leatherworkers, skinners, and tanners
text | 12｜Masons and stonecutters
text | 13｜Painters, limners, and sign-makers
text | 14｜Potters and tile-makers
text | 15｜Shipwrights and sail-makers
text | 16｜Smiths and metal-forgers
text | 17｜Tinkers, pewterers, and casters
text | 18｜Wagon-makers and wheelwrights
text | 19｜Weavers and dyers
text | 20｜Woodcarvers, coopers, and bowyers

description | Suggested Characteristics | Guild artisans are among the most ordinary people in the world—until they set down their tools and take up an adventuring career. They understand the value of hard work and the importance of community, but they're vulnerable to sins of greed and covetousness.
text | d8｜Personality Trait
text | 1｜I believe that anything worth doing is worth doing right. I can't help it—I'm a perfectionist.
text | 2｜I'm a snob who looks down on those who can't appreciate fine art.
text | 3｜I always want to know how things work and what makes people tick.
text | 4｜I'm full of witty aphorisms and have a proverb for every occasion.
text | 5｜I'm rude to people who lack my commitment to hard work and fair play.
text | 6｜I like to talk at length about my profession.
text | 7｜I don't part with my money easily and will haggle tirelessly to get the best deal possible.
text | 8｜I'm well known for my work, and I want to make sure everyone appreciates it. I'm always taken aback when people haven't heard of me.
text | d6｜Ideal
text | 1｜Community. It is the duty of all civilized people to strengthen the bonds of community and the security of civilization. (Lawful)
text | 2｜Generosity. My talents were given to me so that I could use them to benefit the world. (Good)
text | 3｜Freedom. Everyone should be free to pursue his or her own livelihood. (Chaotic)
text | 4｜Greed. I'm only in it for the money. (Evil)
text | 5｜People. I'm committed to the people I care about, not to ideals. (Neutral)
text | 6｜Aspiration. I work hard to be the best there is at my craft. (Any)
text | d6｜Bond
text | 1｜The workshop where I learned my trade is the most important place in the world to me.
text | 2｜I created a great work for someone, and then found them unworthy to receive it. I'm still looking for someone worthy.
text | 3｜I owe my guild a great debt for forging me into the person I am today.
text | 4｜I pursue wealth to secure someone's love.
text | 5｜One day I will return to my guild and prove that I am the greatest artisan of them all.
text | 6｜I will get revenge on the evil forces that destroyed my place of business and ruined my livelihood.
text | d6｜Flaw
text | 1｜I'll do anything to get my hands on something rare or priceless.
text | 2｜I'm quick to assume that someone is trying to cheat me.
text | 3｜No one must ever learn that I once stole money from guild coffers.
text | 4｜I'm never satisfied with what I have—I always want more.
text | 5｜I would kill to acquire a noble title.
text | 6｜I'm horribly jealous of anyone who can outshine my handiwork. Everywhere I go, I'm surrounded by rivals.

title: Baldur's Gate Hermit
contents: bullet | Skill Proficiencies: Medicine, Religion
bullet | Tool Proficiencies: Herbalism kit
bullet | Languages: One of your choice
bullet | Equipment: A scroll case stuffed full of notes from your studies or prayers, a winter blanket, a set of common clothes, an herbalism kit, and 5 gp

description | Feature: Discovery | The quiet seclusion of your extended hermitage gave you access to a unique and powerful discovery. The exact nature of this revelation depends on the nature of your seclusion. It might be a great truth about the cosmos, the deities, the powerful beings of the outer planes, or the forces of nature. It could be a site that no one else has ever seen. You might have uncovered a fact that has long been forgotten, or unearthed some relic of the past that could rewrite history. It might be information that would be damaging to the people who or consigned you to exile, and hence the reason for your return to society.
text | Work with your DM to determine the details of your discovery and its impact on the campaign.

description | Baldur's Gate Feature: The Real City | The effects of a Baldur's Gate feature can be used only while the character is in Baldur's Gate—though, at the DM's discretion, they might have applicable effects in situations similar to those in Baldur's Gate.

text | You know the Baldur's Gate most Baldurians ignore, the dog-eat-dog world of the homeless and unfortunate. You know where to go in the Lower City and Outer City for anonymity. In these slums and alley camps, you can get a damp bed and a bad meal, but also a degree of privacy and no questions asked. Living here isn't comfortable, but it's unlikely anyone will find you—and you can stay as long as you want.

description | Hermit Origins | Any number of personal choices or ill-fated circumstances might have led you to turn away from society. You may, if you wish, choose or roll an origin event from the Hermit Origins table.
text | Hermit Origins
text | d6｜Origin

text | 1｜You led an ill-fated expedition into the Riverveins. Your friends were swept away by flooding, and you've never been able to shake the guilt of causing their deaths over a frivolous lark. You've maintained a solitary vigil outside the cavern entrance ever since.
text | 2｜You crossed the Guild in a bad way. Fortunately, its members think you're dead. Less fortunately, maintaining that deception might require you to stay in hiding until you actually are.

text | 3｜You study the puzzles of mortal natures. You've seen followers of evil deities perform miracles for the helpless at Twin Songs, and you've seen patriars who worship good deities turn their backs on the poor daily. Bearing witness to such things, and meditating on their contradictions, fills your hours.

text | 4｜You tend to some part of the city's forgotten history: the unmarked graves in Cliffside Cemetery, the crumbling remains of dead patriar families' manors, or a collection of religious texts stuffed into an attic and forgotten when a believer's patron deity died. In this solitary work, you've learned secrets no one else knows.
text | 5｜You killed a patriar's scion in an illegal duel. The family swore revenge, and you fled to the slums rather than risk bringing their wrath down on your kin.

text | 6｜You aren't originally from Baldur's Gate. You came here seeking something else, only to learn that the quest that drove you had become impossible to fulfill—its object was destroyed or its purpose was negated by some superseding event. Suddenly directionless and unable to return to your homeland, you have lingered, adrift, in this wretched city.

description | Specialty | What was the reason for your isolation, and what changed to allow you to end your solitude? You can work with your DM to determine the exact nature of your seclusion, or you can choose or roll on the table below to determine the reason behind your seclusion.
text | d8｜Life of Seclusion
text | 1｜I was searching for spiritual enlightenment.
text | 2｜I was partaking of communal living in accordance with the dictates of a religious order.
text | 3｜I was exiled for a crime I didn't commit.
text | 4｜I retreated from society after a life-altering event.
text | 5｜I needed a quiet place to work on my art, literature, music, or manifesto.
text | 6｜I needed to commune with nature, far from civilization.
text | 7｜I was the caretaker of an ancient ruin or relic.
text | 8｜I was a pilgrim in search of a person, place, or relic of spiritual significance.

description | Suggested Characteristics | Some hermits are well suited to a life of seclusion, whereas others chafe against it and long for company. Whether they embrace solitude or long to escape it, the solitary life shapes their attitudes and ideals. A few are driven slightly mad by their years apart from society.
text | d8｜Personality Trait
text | 1｜I've been isolated for so long that I rarely speak, preferring gestures and the occasional grunt.
text | 2｜I am utterly serene, even in the face of disaster.
text | 3｜The leader of my community had something wise to say on every topic, and I am eager to share that wisdom.
text | 4｜I feel tremendous empathy for all who suffer.
text | 5｜I'm oblivious to etiquette and social expectations.
text | 6｜I connect everything that happens to me to a grand, cosmic plan.
text | 7｜I often get lost in my own thoughts and contemplation, becoming oblivious to my surroundings.
text | 8｜I am working on a grand philosophical theory and love sharing my ideas.
text | d6｜Ideal
text | 1｜Greater Good. My gifts are meant to be shared with all, not used for my own benefit. (Good)
text | 2｜Logic. Emotions must not cloud our sense of what is right and true, or our logical thinking. (Lawful)
text | 3｜Free Thinking. Inquiry and curiosity are the pillars of progress. (Chaotic)
text | 4｜Power. Solitude and contemplation are paths toward mystical or magical power. (Evil)
text | 5｜Live and Let Live. Meddling in the affairs of others only causes trouble. (Neutral)
text | 6｜Self-Knowledge. If you know yourself, there's nothing left to know. (Any)
text | d6｜Bond
text | 1｜Nothing is more important than the other members of my hermitage, order, or association.
text | 2｜I entered seclusion to hide from the ones who might still be hunting me. I must someday confront them.
text | 3｜I'm still seeking the enlightenment I pursued in my seclusion, and it still eludes me.
text | 4｜I entered seclusion because I loved someone I could not have.
text | 5｜Should my discovery come to light, it could bring ruin to the world.
text | 6｜My isolation gave me great insight into a great evil that only I can destroy.
text | d6｜Flaw
text | 1｜Now that I've returned to the world, I enjoy its delights a little too much.
text | 2｜I harbor dark, bloodthirsty thoughts that my isolation and meditation failed to quell.
text | 3｜I am dogmatic in my thoughts and philosophy.
text | 4｜I let my need to win arguments overshadow friendships and harmony.
text | 5｜I'd risk too much to uncover a lost bit of knowledge.
text | 6｜I like keeping secrets and won't share them with anyone.

title: Baldur's Gate Noble
contents: bullet | Skill Proficiencies: History, Persuasion
bullet | Tool Proficiencies: One type of gaming set
bullet | Languages: One of your choice
bullet | Equipment: A set of fine clothes, a signet ring, a scroll of pedigree, and a purse containing 25 gp

description | Baldur's Gate Feature: Patriar | The effects of a Baldur's Gate feature can be used only while the character is in Baldur's Gate—though, at the DM's discretion, they might have applicable effects in situations similar to those in Baldur's Gate.

text | As a member of one of the elite families of Baldur's Gate, you may pass through city gates without paying tolls, mingle among the Gate's nobility unquestioned, and impress those on the lookout for wealthy patrons. You are welcome in the Upper City and may stay there after dark without being harassed or evicted. Your word is accepted over others' without question, and any corruption among guards or government officials tends to work in your favor, not against you—at least until you make some effort to expose it.

description | Suggested Characteristics | Nobles are born and raised to a very different lifestyle than most people ever experience, and their personalities reflect that upbringing. A noble title comes with a plethora of bonds—responsibilities to family, to other nobles (including the sovereign), to the people entrusted to the family's care, or even to the title itself. But this responsibility is often a good way to undermine a noble.
text | d8｜Personality Trait
text | 1｜My eloquent flattery makes everyone I talk to feel like the most wonderful and important person in the world.
text | 2｜The common folk love me for my kindness and generosity.
text | 3｜No one could doubt by looking at my regal bearing that I am a cut above the unwashed masses.
text | 4｜I take great pains to always look my best and follow the latest fashions.
text | 5｜I don't like to get my hands dirty, and I won't be caught dead in unsuitable accommodations.
text | 6｜Despite my noble birth, I do not place myself above other folk. We all have the same blood.
text | 7｜My favor, once lost, is lost forever.
text | 8｜If you do me an injury, I will crush you, ruin your name, and salt your fields.
text | d6｜Ideal
text | 1｜Respect. Respect is due to me because of my position, but all people regardless of station deserve to be treated with dignity. (Good)
text | 2｜Responsibility. It is my duty to respect the authority of those above me, just as those below me must respect mine. (Lawful)
text | 3｜Independence. I must prove that I can handle myself without coddling from my family. (Chaotic)
text | 4｜Power. If I can attain more power, no one will tell me what to do. (Evil)
text | 5｜Family. Blood runs thicker than water. (Any)
text | 6｜Noble Obligation. It is my duty to protect and care for the people beneath me. (Good)
text | d6｜Bond
text | 1｜I will face any challenge to win the approval of my family.
text | 2｜My house's alliance with another noble family must be sustained at all costs.
text | 3｜Nothing is more important than the other members of my family.
text | 4｜I am in love with the heir of a family that my family despises.
text | 5｜My loyalty to my sovereign is unwavering.
text | 6｜The common folk must see me as a hero of the people.
text | d6｜Flaw
text | 1｜I secretly believe that everyone is beneath me.
text | 2｜I hide a truly scandalous secret that could ruin my family forever.
text | 3｜I too often hear veiled insults and threats in every word addressed to me, and I'm quick to anger.
text | 4｜I have an insatiable desire for carnal pleasures.
text | 5｜In fact, the world does revolve around me.
text | 6｜By my words and actions, I often bring shame to my family.

title: Baldur's Gate Outlander
contents: bullet | Skill Proficiencies: Athletics, Survival
bullet | Tool Proficiencies: One type of musical instrument
bullet | Languages: One of your choice
bullet | Equipment: A staff, a hunting trap, a trophy from an animal you killed, a set of traveler's clothes, and a belt pouch containing 10 gp

description | Feature: Wanderer | You have an excellent memory for maps and geography, and you can always recall the general layout of terrain, settlements, and other features around you. In addition, you can find food and fresh water for yourself and up to five other people each day, provided that the land offers berries, small game, water, and so forth.

description | Baldur's Gate Feature: Immigrant Experience | The effects of a Baldur's Gate feature can be used only while the character is in Baldur's Gate—though, at the DM's discretion, they might have applicable effects in situations similar to those in Baldur's Gate.

text | Even after your short time in Baldur's Gate, you've learned the city holds more walls and gates than those the Watch and Flaming Fist patrols. You are known within the city's immigrant communities. Should you ever need to learn about a foreign land, people, tradition, or history, you know where to find someone with firsthand experience—likely somewhere in the Outer City.

description | Outlander Origins | Foreigners of all kinds come to Baldur's Gate daily, drawn by countless reasons from countless lands. The Outlander Origins table provides ideas for how your character might have come to Baldur's Gate.
text | Outlander Origins
text | d6｜Origin

text | 1｜Someone stole something precious from your people. You tracked the thief to the city gates, but finding clues in an urban environment is very different from tracking someone across the wilderness. You don't know where to go from here, but your people need you to succeed.

text | 2｜You've always been fascinated by the glitter and glamor of city life, so different from the slow pace of life in your homeland. Now you're here, ready to make your mark in the world, but unsure how to begin.

text | 3｜War, plague, famine, or a marauding monster ravaged your home, forcing you to flee for your life. You don't even know how many of your people survived or where to find them. Alone or accompanied by a handful of equally bereft survivors, you must navigate a new life that you never asked for.
text | 4｜You were captured by kidnappers and taken far from your home. The Knights of the Unicorn freed you and brought you here, but now you're on your own.

text | 5｜You were exiled for breaking a trivial-seeming taboo. For this seemingly minor transgression, you lost your friends, family, and homeland in one fell swoop, and were given little choice but to strike out on your own.

text | 6｜A peddler once brought something astonishing to your homeland—a Gondan clockwork, shimmering cloth of gold, a trained speaking bird, or some other small wonder—and told you that it came from Baldur's Gate. You've come to see the source of such wonders, and perhaps learn to create them.

description | Specialty | You've been to strange places and seen things that others cannot begin to fathom. Consider some of the distant lands you have visited, and how they impacted you. You can roll on the following table to determine your occupation during your time in the wild, or choose one that best fits your character.
text | d10｜Origin
text | 1｜Forester
text | 2｜Trapper
text | 3｜Homesteader
text | 4｜Guide
text | 5｜Exile or outcast
text | 6｜Bounty hunter
text | 7｜Pilgrim
text | 8｜Tribal nomad
text | 9｜Hunter-gatherer
text | 10｜Tribal marauder

description | Suggested Characteristics | Often considered rude and uncouth among civilized folk, outlanders have little respect for the niceties of life in the cities. The ties of tribe, clan, family, and the natural world of which they are a part are the most important bonds to most outlanders.
text | d8｜Personality Trait
text | 1｜I'm driven by a wanderlust that led me away from home.
text | 2｜I watch over my friends as if they were a litter of newborn pups.
text | 3｜I once ran twenty-five miles without stopping to warn to my clan of an approaching orc horde. I'd do it again if I had to.
text | 4｜I have a lesson for every situation, drawn from observing nature.
text | 5｜I place no stock in wealthy or well-mannered folk. Money and manners won't save you from a hungry owlbear.
text | 6｜I'm always picking things up, absently fiddling with them, and sometimes accidentally breaking them.
text | 7｜I feel far more comfortable around animals than people.
text | 8｜I was, in fact, raised by wolves.
text | d6｜Ideal
text | 1｜Change. Life is like the seasons, in constant change, and we must change with it. (Chaotic)
text | 2｜Greater Good. It is each person's responsibility to make the most happiness for the whole tribe. (Good)
text | 3｜Honor. If I dishonor myself, I dishonor my whole clan. (Lawful)
text | 4｜Might. The strongest are meant to rule. (Evil)
text | 5｜Nature. The natural world is more important than all the constructs of civilization. (Neutral)
text | 6｜Glory. I must earn glory in battle, for myself and my clan. (Any)
text | d6｜Bond
text | 1｜My family, clan, or tribe is the most important thing in my life, even when they are far from me.
text | 2｜An injury to the unspoiled wilderness of my home is an injury to me.
text | 3｜I will bring terrible wrath down on the evildoers who destroyed my homeland.
text | 4｜I am the last of my tribe, and it is up to me to ensure their names enter legend.
text | 5｜I suffer awful visions of a coming disaster and will do anything to prevent it.
text | 6｜It is my duty to provide children to sustain my tribe.
text | d6｜Flaw
text | 1｜I am too enamored of ale, wine, and other intoxicants.
text | 2｜There's no room for caution in a life lived to the fullest.
text | 3｜I remember every insult I've received and nurse a silent resentment toward anyone who's ever wronged me.
text | 4｜I am slow to trust members of other races, tribes, and societies.
text | 5｜Violence is my answer to almost any challenge.
text | 6｜Don't expect me to save those who can't save themselves. It is nature's way that the strong thrive and the weak perish.

title: Baldur's Gate Sage
contents: bullet | Skill Proficiencies: Arcana, History
bullet | Languages: Two of your choice

bullet | Equipment: A bottle of black ink, a quill, a small knife, a letter from a dead colleague posing a question you have not yet been able to answer, a set of common clothes, and a belt pouch containing 10 gp

description | Feature: Researcher | When you attempt to learn or recall a piece of lore, if you do not know that information, you often know where and from whom you can obtain it. Usually, this information comes from a library, scriptorium, university, or a sage or other learned person or creature. Your DM might rule that the knowledge you seek is secreted away in an almost inaccessible place, or that it simply cannot be found. Unearthing the deepest secrets of the multiverse can require an adventure or even a whole campaign.

description | Baldur's Gate Feature: Rumor Monger | The effects of a Baldur's Gate feature can be used only while the character is in Baldur's Gate—though, at the DM's discretion, they might have applicable effects in situations similar to those in Baldur's Gate.

text | Via your personal rumor mill and articles published in Baldur's Mouth, you can surmise a great deal about Baldurians' secrets—who's practicing necromancy, who's involved in spying or smuggling, who would purchase or craft dangerous magical wares without batting an eyelash. Whenever a noteworthy crime or mysterious happening occurs in the city, you immediately have a list of 1d4 suspects who, if they aren't involved, have a strong chance of knowing who is.
description | Specialty | To determine the nature of your scholarly training, roll a d8 or choose from the options in the table below.
text | d8｜Field of Study
text | 1｜Alchemist
text | 2｜Astronomer
text | 3｜Discredited academic
text | 4｜Librarian
text | 5｜Professor
text | 6｜Researcher
text | 7｜Wizard's apprentice
text | 8｜Scribe

description | Suggested Characteristics | Sages are defined by their extensive studies, and their characteristics reflect this life of study. Devoted to scholarly pursuits, a sage values knowledge highly—sometimes in its own right, sometimes as a means toward other ideals.
text | d8｜Personality Trait
text | 1｜I use polysyllabic words that convey the impression of great erudition.
text | 2｜I've read every book in the world's greatest libraries—or I like to boast that I have.
text | 3｜I'm used to helping out those who aren't as smart as I am, and I patiently explain anything and everything to others.
text | 4｜There's nothing I like more than a good mystery.
text | 5｜I'm willing to listen to every side of an argument before I make my own judgment.
text | 6｜I... speak... slowly... when talking... to idiots,... which... almost... everyone... is... compared... to me.
text | 7｜I am horribly, horribly awkward in social situations.
text | 8｜I'm convinced that people are always trying to steal my secrets.
text | d6｜Ideal
text | 1｜Knowledge. The path to power and self-improvement is through knowledge. (Neutral)
text | 2｜Beauty. What is beautiful points us beyond itself toward what is true. (Good)
text | 3｜Logic. Emotions must not cloud our logical thinking. (Lawful)
text | 4｜No Limits. Nothing should fetter the infinite possibility inherent in all existence. (Chaotic)
text | 5｜Power. Knowledge is the path to power and domination. (Evil)
text | 6｜Self-Improvement. The goal of a life of study is the betterment of oneself. (Any)
text | d6｜Bond
text | 1｜It is my duty to protect my students.
text | 2｜I have an ancient text that holds terrible secrets that must not fall into the wrong hands.
text | 3｜I work to preserve a library, university, scriptorium, or monastery.
text | 4｜My life's work is a series of tomes related to a specific field of lore.
text | 5｜I've been searching my whole life for the answer to a certain question.
text | 6｜I sold my soul for knowledge. I hope to do great deeds and win it back.
text | d6｜Flaw
text | 1｜I am easily distracted by the promise of information.
text | 2｜Most people scream and run when they see a demon. I stop and take notes on its anatomy.
text | 3｜Unlocking an ancient mystery is worth the price of a civilization.
text | 4｜I overlook obvious solutions in favor of complicated ones.
text | 5｜I speak without really thinking through my words, invariably insulting others.
text | 6｜I can't keep a secret to save my life, or anyone else's.

title: Baldur's Gate Sailor
contents: bullet | Skill Proficiencies: Athletics, Perception
bullet | Tool Proficiencies: Navigator's tools, vehicles (water)

bullet | Equipment: A belaying pin (club), silk rope (50 feet), a lucky charm such as a rabbit foot or a small stone with a hole in the center (or you may roll for a random trinket on the Trinkets table in chapter 5), a set of common clothes, and a belt pouch containing 10 gp

description | Feature: Ship's Passage | When you need to, you can secure free passage on a sailing ship for yourself and your adventuring companions. You might sail on the ship you served on, or another ship you have good relations with (perhaps one captained by a former crewmate). Because you're calling in a favor, you can't be certain of a schedule or route that will meet your every need. Your Dungeon Master will determine how long it takes to get where you need to go. In return for your free passage, you and your companions are expected to assist the crew during the voyage.

description | Baldur's Gate Feature: Smuggler's Sense | The effects of a Baldur's Gate feature can be used only while the character is in Baldur's Gate—though, at the DM's discretion, they might have applicable effects in situations similar to those in Baldur's Gate.

text | You're familiar with the docks of Baldur's Gate, the movement of inspectors and tax collectors, the way cargo and coin flows. As a result, it's easy for you to hustle a load of cargo ashore or see such a cargo onto a cooperative ship without attracting suspicion or taxation. You also know the movements of the Gray Wavers—the Flaming Fist harbor guards—and have a sense of how to operate the city's mechanized cranes.

description | Suggested Characteristics | Sailors can be a rough lot, but the responsibilities of life on a ship make them generally reliable as well. Life aboard a ship shapes their outlook and forms their most important attachments.
text | d8｜Personality Trait
text | 1｜My friends know they can rely on me, no matter what.
text | 2｜I work hard so that I can play hard when the work is done.
text | 3｜I enjoy sailing into new ports and making new friends over a flagon of ale.
text | 4｜I stretch the truth for the sake of a good story.
text | 5｜To me, a tavern brawl is a nice way to get to know a new city.
text | 6｜I never pass up a friendly wager.
text | 7｜My language is as foul as an otyugh nest.
text | 8｜I like a job well done, especially if I can convince someone else to do it.
text | d6｜Ideal
text | 1｜Respect. The thing that keeps a ship together is mutual respect between captain and crew. (Good)
text | 2｜Fairness. We all do the work, so we all share in the rewards. (Lawful)
text | 3｜Freedom. The sea is freedom—the freedom to go anywhere and do anything. (Chaotic)
text | 4｜Mastery. I'm a predator, and the other ships on the sea are my prey. (Evil)
text | 5｜People. I'm committed to my crewmates, not to ideals. (Neutral)
text | 6｜Aspiration. Someday, I'll own my own ship and chart my own destiny. (Any)
text | d6｜Bond
text | 1｜I'm loyal to my captain first, everything else second.
text | 2｜The ship is most important—crewmates and captains come and go.
text | 3｜I'll always remember my first ship.
text | 4｜In a harbor town, I have a paramour whose eyes nearly stole me from the sea.
text | 5｜I was cheated out of my fair share of the profits, and I want to get my due.
text | 6｜Ruthless pirates murdered my captain and crewmates, plundered our ship, and left me to die. Vengeance will be mine.
text | d6｜Flaw
text | 1｜I follow orders, even if I think they're wrong.
text | 2｜I'll say anything to avoid having to do extra work.
text | 3｜Once someone questions my courage, I never back down no matter how dangerous the situation.
text | 4｜Once I start drinking, it's hard for me to stop.
text | 5｜I can't help but pocket loose coins and other trinkets I come across.
text | 6｜My pride will probably lead to my destruction.

title: Baldur's Gate Soldier
contents: bullet | Skill Proficiencies: Athletics, Intimidation
bullet | Tool Proficiencies: One type of gaming set, vehicles (land)

bullet | Equipment: An insignia of rank, a trophy taken from a fallen enemy (a dagger, broken blade, or piece of a banner), a bone dice set or playing card set, a set of common clothes, and a belt pouch containing 10 gp

description | Feature: Military Rank | You have a military rank from your career as a soldier. Soldiers loyal to your former military organization still recognize your authority and influence, and they defer to you if they are of a lower rank. You can invoke your rank to exert influence over other soldiers and requisition simple equipment or horses for temporary use. You can also usually gain access to friendly military encampments and fortresses where your rank is recognized.
